page.title: Cultural impact of The Colbert Report

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/162.245.248.188|162.245.248.188]] to version by InternetArchiveBot. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3551636) (Bot)
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Cultural impact of ''The Colbert Report''}} [[File:Flickr - The U.S. Army - Stephen Colbert in Iraq (2).jpg|thumb|Stephen Colbert interviewing a member of the U.S. army]] ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', which premiered in American cable television on October 17, 2005, has had a massive cultural impact since its inception, when the show introduced the word "[[truthiness]]". Issues in and references to American and world culture are attributed to the character played by [[Stephen Colbert]], who calls his followers the Colbert Nation. ''The Colbert Report'' is a [[late night television|late-night]] [[Late-night talk show|talk]] and [[news satire]] [[television program]] hosted by [[Stephen Colbert]] that aired on [[Comedy Central]] from October 17, 2005 to December 18, 2014 for 1,447 episodes. The show focused on a [[Stephen Colbert (character)|fictional anchorman character named Stephen Colbert]], played by his real-life namesake. The character, described by Colbert as a "well-intentioned, poorly informed, high-status [[Idiot (usage)|idiot]]", is a caricature of televised political [[pundit]]s. Furthermore, the show satirized conservative personality-driven political talk programs, particularly [[Fox News]]' ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]''. ''The Colbert Report'' is a [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of Comedy Central's ''[[The Daily Show]]'', where he acted as a [[correspondent]] for the program for several years while developing the character.
The program was created by Colbert, [[Jon Stewart]], and [[Ben Karlin]]. The show's writing was grounded in [[improvisation]], and often lampooned [[current events]] stories. The show's structure also included a guest interview, in which the Colbert character attempts to deconstruct his opponent's argument. The show was taped in [[New York City]]'s [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]] neighborhood, and the program's set is "hyper-American," epitomizing the character's ego. The show was taped and broadcast Monday through Thursday, with weeks taken off at multiple points in a given year for breaks. ''The Colbert Report'' saw immediate critical and ratings successes, leading to various awards, including two prestigious [[Peabody Award]]s. The show's cultural influence—which occasionally would require a fair degree of participation from the show’s audience, dubbed the "Colbert Nation"—extended beyond the program a number of times. This impact included the character running for [[U.S. President]] twice, co-hosting a [[Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear|rally]] at the [[National Mall]], presenting a [[Stephen Colbert at the 2006 White House Correspondents' Association Dinner|controversial performance]] at the [[White House Correspondents' Association|White House Correspondents' Dinner]], and establishing a real [[Colbert Super PAC|Super PAC]] that raised a million dollars. In addition, the show inspired various forms of multimedia, including music and multiple best-selling books.
==Presented as non-satirical journalism== In May 2006, the [[Tom DeLay]] Legal Defense Trust posted a video of ''The Colbert Report'' on its website and sent out a mass email urging DeLay supporters to watch how "Hollywood liberal" [[Robert Greenwald]] "crashed and burned . . . when promoting his new attack on Tom DeLay."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2006/05/delay.JPG|title=Defend DeLay|publisher=Think Progress|date=May 2006|accessdate=September 2, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080904202222/http://thinkprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2006/05/delay.JPG|archivedate=September 4, 2008|df=}}</ref> The video featured Colbert asking questions such as, "Who hates America more, you or [[Michael Moore]]?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/2006/05/24/delay-colbert/|title=Desperate for Supporters, DeLay Turns to Stephen Colbert|publisher=Think Progress|date=May 24, 2006|accessdate=September 2, 2008}}</ref> The Trust's email describes its content as "the truth behind Liberal Hollywood's" [[The Big Buy: Tom DeLay's Stolen Congress|film about DeLay]], and characterizes the ''Colbert Report'' clip with the headline, "Colbert Cracks the Story on Real Motivations Behind the Movie." On June 8, 2006, Colbert responded by conducting an "Exclusive Fake Interview" on his show with DeLay. Three different interviews with DeLay on different networks were spliced for humorous effect, and Colbert ended the "interview" by saying "I do hope you enjoyed my manipulation of your words." DeLay has since appeared as a guest on the program.
On July 25, 2006,<ref>[http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/182106/july-25-2006/morning-shows Morning Shows – The Colbert Report – 2006-25-07 – Video Clip | Comedy Central]. Colbertnation.com (July 25, 2006). Retrieved June 4, 2012.</ref> Colbert responded to television networks—specifically [[Fox News]], NBC's ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'' and ABC's ''[[Good Morning America]]''—which took comments made by Florida Congressman [[Robert Wexler]] on ''The Colbert Report'' out of context (e.g.: "I enjoy cocaine and the company of prostitutes because they are a fun thing to do."). Wexler, who ran unopposed in the then-upcoming election, made the comments in response to urging by Colbert that he "say some things that would really lose the election for [Wexler] if [Wexler] were contested."<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |title=Rep. Wexler Vows He Was Joking When He Made Cocaine Remark |date=July 24, 2006 |publisher=Fox News |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,205314,00.html |accessdate=September 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414082009/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C205314%2C00.html |archivedate=April 14, 2008 |df= }}</ref> Colbert criticized the major networks' morning news shows that featured the interview in a misleading and a negative light, by showing clips from many of the "fluff" pieces they favored instead of "real" news. Colbert subsequently told his viewers to "vote Wexler, the man's got a sense of humor, unlike, evidently, journalists."
==Animals named for Stephen Colbert== Colbert announced on his March 28, 2006 show that he had been contacted by [[San Francisco Zoo]] officials seeking his permission to name an unhatched [[bald eagle]] after him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/03/31/DDGU9GJ5T21.DTL |title=Leah Garchik |last=Garchik |first=Leah |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=March 31, 2006 |accessdate=September 2, 2008}}</ref> The eagle, affectionately dubbed Stephen Jr. on ''The Report'', was bred to be reintroduced into the wild, as a part of the zoo's California Bald Eagle Breeding Program. Colbert celebrated the chick's birth on the April 17, 2006, program, and has since given updates on the bird's development. He has criticized the bird for migrating to Canada, and has attempted to lure him back to the U.S. On December 24, 2008, Stephen Jr. (tag A-46) was photographed at the Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge on the California/Oregon border.<ref>[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2008568404_colberteagle29m.html A Colbert report: Bald eagle Stephen Jr. sighted in Oregon | Seattle Times Newspaper] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112092040/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2008568404_colberteagle29m.html |date=2012-01-12 }}. Seattletimes.nwsource.com. Retrieved June 4, 2012.</ref>
On September 30, 2006, the [[Saginaw Spirit]], an [[Ontario Hockey League|OHL]] hockey team in [[Saginaw, Michigan]], named its co-mascot Steagle Colbeagle the Eagle in honor of Colbert, despite the fact that it was spotted holding a Canadian flag during the anthem.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.saginawspirit.com/ss/home.nsf/public/F1B124E7E7059E19852571FD0041E8B7 |title=The Colbert Report Spotlights Spirit |publisher=[[Saginaw Spirit]] |date=September 30, 2006 |accessdate= September 2, 2008| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528182121/http://www.saginawspirit.com/ss/home.nsf/public/F1B124E7E7059E19852571FD0041E8B7| archivedate = May 28, 2008}}</ref> Before the introduction of the mascot, the team record was 0–3–0–1, but once the Steagle was introduced, the team improved their record to 44–21–0–3 by the season's end,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ontariohockeyleague.com/stats/statdisplay.php?type=standings&subType=0&season_id=29&league_id=1&lastActive= |title=OHL standings |publisher=[[Ontario Hockey League|OHL]] |date=January 6, 2007 |accessdate= September 2, 2008| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080619233248/http://www.ontariohockeyleague.com/stats/statdisplay.php?type=standings&subType=0&season_id=29&league_id=1&lastActive=| archivedate = June 19, 2008}}</ref> before losing in the first round of the playoffs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ontariohockeyleague.com/hm/bracket.php?view=brief |title=2007 Playoff Brackets |accessdate= September 2, 2008 |publisher=[[Ontario Hockey League|OHL]] | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080602183939/http://www.ontariohockeyleague.com/hm/bracket.php?view=brief| archivedate = June 2, 2008}}</ref> On January 27, 2007, [[Oshawa, Ontario]] declared March 20 of that year (John Gray's birthday) Stephen Colbert Day after mayor John Gray bet Colbert that the [[Oshawa Generals]] would beat the Spirit, and Saginaw won 5–4.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16842683/ |title=Hockey team ensures 'Stephen Colbert Day' |date=January 27, 2007 |accessdate=March 16, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070203224010/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16842683/ |archivedate=February 3, 2007 }}</ref>
In the latter part of March 2007, Drexel University named a [[leatherback turtle]] in honor of Colbert in their Great Turtle Race.<ref>{{cite news | last =Lopez | first = Tatiana | title =Follow a turtle race on the Web | date= March 13, 2007 | url =https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/2007-04-16-turtle-race_N.htm | accessdate = September 2, 2008 | work=USA Today}}</ref> "Stephanie Colburtle the [[Leatherback Turtle]]" came in second place, losing to a turtle named Billie.<ref>{{cite web|last=Drexel University |title=Four turtles are done! |date=April 27, 2007 |url=http://www.drexel.edu/bioscience/turtleblog/index.html |accessdate=September 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719222323/http://www.drexel.edu/bioscience/turtleblog/index.html |archivedate=July 19, 2008 }}</ref>
On June 24, 2008, [[Jason Bond|Dr. Jason Bond]], an associate professor with the Department of [[Biology]] at [[East Carolina University]], appeared on the show because he agreed to name a [[spider]] after Stephen Colbert. They negotiated over what kind of spider would be named after Stephen, and Colbert told the professor that they would "settle this in the next couple of weeks". During the interview, the visual approximation of Bond changed between different pictures depicting [[Spider-Man]], including [[Tobey Maguire]] (the actor who played Spider-Man in the films) and costumed people/animals. The spider was officially announced on August 6 as the ''[[Aptostichus stephencolberti]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/25956273/|title=Trapdoor spider becomes Colbert's namesake|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=July 31, 2008|accessdate=August 3, 2008}}</ref>
Colbert announced on February 5, 2009 that the [[UC Santa Cruz]] Marine Lab named an [[elephant seal]] in honor of him: Stelephant Colbert the Elephant Seal.
==Places and things named for Stephen Colbert== In 2006, the ice hockey team [[Saginaw Spirit]] named their mini mascot "Steagle Colbeagle" after they held a naming contest. As of 2014, the team still had Steagle Colbeagle as their mini mascot.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/saginaw/index.ssf/2014/12/stephen_coberts_legacy_include.html |title=Stephen Colbert gives shout out to Saginaw Spirit's 'Steagle Colbeagle' mini mascot during final show |last=Shepherd |first=Jessica |website=MLive.com |publication-date=19 December 2014}}</ref>
In February 2007, [[Ben & Jerry's]] unveiled a new ice cream flavor in honor of Stephen Colbert, named [[Stephen Colbert's AmeriCone Dream]] (available only in the United States). Colbert waited until [[Easter]] to sample the ice cream because he "gave up sweets for [[Lent]]."<ref>{{cite news|author = Freydkin, Donna|url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2007-03-06-colbert-ice-cream_N.htm|title = As AmeriCone as ice cream|publisher = [[USA TODAY]]|date = March 6, 2007|accessdate = 2007-03-06}}</ref> Colbert will donate all proceeds to charity through the new Stephen Colbert AmeriCone Dream Fund, which will distribute the money to various causes.<ref>{{cite web|author = [[Associated Press]]|title=Ben & Jerry's names new flavor for Colbert|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=February 15, 2007|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17152896/|accessdate = 2007-03-04}}</ref> The flavor is described as "a decadent melting pot of vanilla ice cream with fudge-covered waffle cone pieces and a caramel swirl."<ref>{{cite web | title =Stephen Colbert's AmeriCone Dream | publisher = [[Ben & Jerry's]] | url =http://www.benjerry.com/flavors/americone-dream-ice-cream | accessdate = September 2, 2008 }}</ref> The company's founders appeared on the show on March 5, 2007 to discuss the ice cream and to plug their "grassroots education and advocacy project", [[TrueMajority]].
On August 22, 2007, [[Richard Branson]], who was being interviewed as a guest, announced that one of his ''[[Virgin America]]'' [[aeroplanes]] would be named Air Colbert. Colbert announced on April 2, 2008, during a ThreatDown segment, that the plane had been grounded after one of its engines was damaged by a [[bird strike]].
During the sweepstakes for naming the new wing on the [[International Space Station]], Stephen Colbert announced on his show that there was a write-in section where you could write your own suggestion for a name in. He encouraged his fans to write in "Colbert". When the sweepstakes was over, NASA announced that "Colbert" had beaten the next-most-popular choice, "Serenity," by over 40,000 votes on March 11, 2009. "Colbert" received 230,539 votes out of nearly 1.2 million cast.<ref>{{cite news|title='Colbert' Wins Space-Station Module Name Contest|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,510211,00.html|work=Associated Press, via Fox News|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=July 16, 2011|date=March 24, 2009}}</ref>
On April 15, 2009, NASA announced that instead of the new module being named after him, a treadmill on board the space station would be called the Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill (C.O.L.B.E.R.T.).<ref name="NASA">{{cite web |title=Station Module Named 'Tranquility' to Honor Apollo 11 |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/behindscenes/node3_name.html |date=April 15, 2009 |publisher=[[NASA]] |accessdate=August 17, 2009}}</ref>
==Honors bestowed by media organizations== ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's James Poniewozik named it one of the Top 10 Returning Series of 2007, ranking it at #7.<ref>Poniewozik, James. (December 9, 2007) [http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/top10/article/0,30583,1686204_1686244_1691408,00.html Poniewozik, James; Top 10 New TV Series;]. Time.com. Retrieved June 4, 2012.</ref>
Colbert has appeared on the covers of several major magazines, including ''Wired'', ''Rolling Stone'', ''Esquire'', ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' (as sponsor of the US Speedskating team) and ''Newsweek'', in which he was the Guest Editor.
On March 12, 2007, the Editor-in-Chief of [[Marvel Comics]], [[Joe Quesada]], awarded Stephen Colbert the [[Captain America's shield|shield]] of the recently deceased superhero [[Captain America]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[Marvel Comics]] |work=Marvel News |title=The Colbert Report covers the Death of Captain America |date=March 9, 2007 |url=http://www.marvel.com/news/-1.880 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130129121749/http://www.marvel.com/news/-1.880 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 29, 2013 |accessdate=September 2, 2008 }}</ref> The letter to Colbert accompanying the shield stated that "[[Captain America|the Star-Spangled Avenger]] has bequeathed... his indestructible shield to the only man he believed to have the red, white, and blue balls to carry the mantle." Colbert promised to use the shield "only to fight for justice...and to impress girls." It was, in fact, one of only two full-sized prop shields which had previously been kept in the Marvel offices.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brady |first=Matt |title=Colbert Gets Cap's Shield |date=March 13, 2007 |url=http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=104912 |accessdate=September 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210135451/http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=104912 |archivedate=December 10, 2008 |df= }}</ref> On January 29, 2008, Quesada (now president of Marvel) returned to announce that Colbert's fictional campaign for the presidency was still active in the Marvel universe, references to which have appeared in Marvel comics since. Colbert appears on the cover of ''Amazing Spider-Man #573''.
At the end of 2008, ''The Colbert Report'' was named the number one television series of that year by ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''.
In 2010 Colbert won the Golden Tweet Award.<ref name="GoldenTweet">[https://blog.twitter.com/2010/hindsight2010-year%E2%80%99s-most-retweeted-tweets# Official Twitter blog], entry #Hindsights2010. "Twitter is awarding Colbert —the titan of ‘Truthiness’— the first-ever Golden Tweet award for the year’s Most Retweeted Tweet."</ref>
==Arts== On October 17, 2008, it was announced that the portrait of Stephen from his second year of ''The Colbert Report'' was accepted into the national portrait collection at the [[National Museum of American History]] for its November reopening.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}}
==Athletics== On November 2, 2009, Colbert, representing the Colbert Nation, signed an on-air sponsorship agreement with U.S. speedskating executive director Robert Crowley.<ref name="autogenerated1">[http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/news/story?id=4618388 'Colbert Report' will sponsor U.S. speedskating squad].</ref> Fundraising via ''The Colbert Report'' ultimately raised $300,000 for the US Winter Olympics speedskating team.<ref>[http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/262175/january-19-2010/skate-expectations---speedskating-team-training Skate Expectations: Speedskating Team Training], on ''The Colbert Report'' "Tues, Jan 19, 2010"</ref> Coverage of the show's efforts also led to Colbert personally being invited to be the official [[ombudsman]] at the oval for the Olympics,<ref name="hrs1">{{cite web | title = Richmond declares war on Stephen Colbert | publisher = [[24 Hours (newspaper)|24 Hours Vancouver]] | url = http://vancouver.24hrs.ca/Sports/vancouver2010/2009/11/17/pf-11777571.html | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120716174722/http://vancouver.24hrs.ca/Sports/vancouver2010/2009/11/17/pf-11777571.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = July 16, 2012 | accessdate = November 22, 2009}}</ref> appointed as the official assistant sports psychologist for the US [[olympics]] speed skating team, and as such is now an official member of the team,<ref>Colbert Nation http://www.colbertnation.com/home</ref><ref>[http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/262387/january-20-2010/skate-expectations---speedskating-race---shani-davis Skate Expectations: Speedskating Race with Shani Davis], on ''The Colbert Report'' "Wed, Jan 20, 2010"</ref> and invited by [[Dick Ebersol]], to be part of [[NBC]]'s 2010 Winter Olympics coverage team.<ref>[http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/262388/january-20-2010/dick-ebersol Interview with Dick Ebersol], on ''The Colbert Report'' "Wed, Jan 20, 2010"</ref>
==Congressional response== In response to the "Better Know a District" segment, [[Rahm Emanuel]], then the Democratic Caucus chair, instructed incoming freshmen not to do appearances on the show.<ref name="The Hill">{{cite news | last =Kaplan | first =Jonathan E. | title =Emanuel tells freshmen to avoid Stephen Colbert | publisher =[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date= 2007-03-14 | url = http://thehill.com/homenews/news/11329-emanuel-tells-freshmen-to-avoid-stephen-colbert | accessdate = 2014-04-11 }}</ref>
==Neologisms== ''The Colbert Report'' has created new words. Besides "[[truthiness]]", Colbert has coined other terms including "freem", which is "freedom without the do, because I do it all for you."<ref>{{cite web | title =Possible origin of Freem? | date=2007-01-10 | url =http://www.nofactzone.net/?p=724|publisher=No Fact Zone | accessdate =2008-09-02}}</ref> Other words include: "eneagled", a [[blend word|blend]] of "enabled" and "eagle", thus meaning "to be given the characteristics of an eagle" and "mantasy", meaning male fantasies, such as running away from the wife to become free, a word to which Colbert claims to hold a trademark. In 2009, he coined the word "engayify" meaning "to gay it up."<ref>{{cite web | title =Colbert Report: Toby Keith | work = TV.com | date=2007-06-20| url =http://www.tv.com/the-colbert-report/toby-keith/episode/1075931/summary.html | accessdate =2008-09-02 }}</ref>
==Wikipedia references== Colbert made repeated references on the show to [[Wikipedia]], which he referred to as his favorite website, generally in "[[The Wørd]]" segment. Colbert's first reference to Wikipedia was during the July 31, 2006 broadcast, when "The Word" was [[Wikiality]], defined as the concept that "[[Truth by consensus|together we can create a reality that we all agree on—the reality we just agreed on]]".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=72347 | title=Video: The Colbert Report, Wikiality | date=2006-07-31 | authorlink=Stephen Colbert | first=Stephen|last=Colbert| accessdate=2007-05-25 | publisher=[[Comedy Central]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080308053730/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=72347 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-03-08}}</ref> The premise of wikiality is that reality is what the wiki says it is.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sanger, Larry|title=Who says we know: On the new politics of knowledge|url=http://www.edge.org/3rd_culture/sanger07/sanger07_index.html|work=Edge.com}}</ref> He explained that on Wikipedia "any user can change any entry, and if enough users agree with them, it becomes true". He also told his viewers to edit the Wikipedia article on [[elephant]]s to edit say: "Elephant population in Africa has tripled over the past six months." The suggestion resulted in numerous changes to Wikipedia articles related to elephants and Africa. Editing of the articles concerned was restricted to prevent further edits. The pages' protection expiration date has been postponed several times as the vandalism ensued again.
Another Colbert neologism related to Wikipedia is "Wikilobbying", regarding which he stated "when money determines Wikipedia entries, reality has become a commodity". He alluded to a case involving controversy over whether governments should reject a [[Microsoft]] document format in favor of an independent standard, during which Microsoft allegedly hired a Linux user to edit Wikipedia to ensure neutral and factual coverage of Microsoft's version.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.oreillynet.com/xml/blog/2007/01/an_interesting_offer.html | title=An interesting offer: get paid to contribute to Wikipedia | date=2007-01-22 | first=Rick |last=Jeliffe | accessdate=2008-09-02 | work=O'Reilly XML Blog|publisher=oreillynet.com }}</ref> Colbert used the term "[[self-determination]]" to refer to corporations being able to act out their fantasies online by editing their own Wikipedia entries. Colbert described Wikipedia as "''[[Second Life]]'' for corporations", saying that if a corporation wants to pretend to be someone else online, then that is their business.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/183247/august-21-2007/the-word---self-determination|title="The Word" - Self-Determination|publisher=[[Comedy Central]]|date=2007-08-21|accessdate=2008-09-02}}</ref>
In another episode, guest Dan Zaccagnino was discussing his [[Indaba Music|new wiki]] where readers could share their musical compositions. In an imitation of [[record scratching]], Colbert used the term "Wiki-Wiki-Wikipedia".
On May 24, 2007, the guest was [[Jimmy Wales]], the co-founder of Wikipedia. Stephen Colbert called Wikipedia a "battlefield for information", a tool which "brings democracy to information" and moves away from the views of the "elite who study things and get to say what is or is not real". During the interview, Colbert showed a sentence on the screen, "Librarians are hiding something." Wales was not allowed to see it, implying that he could not personally stop a critical mass of individuals from editing a page when he did not know which page was the target. Wales responded that "the interesting thing about ''The Colbert Report'' is that [[Wikipedia community|Wikipedians]] watch it".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=87528|title=Jimmy Wales|publisher=[[Comedy Central]]|date=2007-05-24|accessdate=2008-09-02 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080510170626/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=87528 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-05-10}}</ref>
On June 9, 2008, Colbert mentioned [[Warren G. Harding]] as being a "secret negro president", and said that for proof, "the G stands for Gangsta" which he edited Wikipedia to state so that he could cite a source.<ref>{{cite web |work=The Colbert Report |url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/172954/june-09-2008/threatdown---secret-negro-presidents |title=ThreatDown – Secret Negro Presidents |date=2008-06-09 |first=Stephen |last=Colbert}}</ref>
==Hungarian bridge campaign== <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[Image:colbert-zrinyi.jpg|thumb|right|[[Stephen Colbert|Colbert]] refers to [[Nikola Zrinski|Miklós Zrínyi]] in promoting the bridge contest]] -->
{{Further|Megyeri Bridge}}
In 2006, the Ministry of Transport of [[Hungary]] launched an online call for public suggestions to name a [[Northern M0 Danube bridge|future motorway bridge]] over the [[Danube]], just north of [[Budapest]]. Ministry officials said the [[Hungarian Geographical Name Committee]] would choose from among the three submitted candidates with the most votes, guided by suggestions submitted by "local governments, cartographers, linguists, and other experts".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20060801/od_uk_nm/oukoe_uk_hungary_bridge;_ylt=AvtgRZjeCP4uwq1l.aL2kbys0NUE;_ylu=X3oDMTA3NW1oMDRpBHNlYwM3NTc-|title=Chuck Norris leads vote for Budapest bridge name|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=2006-08-01}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} (link dead as of July 26, 2007)</ref> Users offered hundreds of suggestions, among them the "'You Can Go To Bratislava But Not Over This Bridge' Bridge" and the "Chuck Norris Bridge", which led in votes for some time.<ref name="Sklar">{{cite news | last =Sklar | first =Rachel | title =Stephen Colbert's Web Dominance: How "The Colbert Report" Is Fast Becoming The Leader In Web-TV Integration | date= 2006-08-22 | url =http://www.huffingtonpost.com/eat-the-press/2006/08/22/stephen-colberts-web-dom_e_27670.html | accessdate = 2008-09-02 | work=Huffington Post}}</ref> Colbert noted the effort in his "Tip of the hat, wag of the finger" segment on August 9,<ref name=Tip>{{cite web| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UtjTt8RriTA|title = Colbert Report - Tip of the Hat, Wag of the Finger| accessdate = 2006-09-04 | date = 2006-08-09 | format = Video | publisher = [[YouTube]]}}</ref> and in the following weeks, he continued to ask viewers to vote for him. On August 22, Hungarian news sites reported Colbert had won the first round of voting with 17,231,724 votes,<ref name=First_round>{{cite web| url = http://index.hu/gazdasag/magyar/colb060822/ | title = A seggfej Zrínyi előtt amerikai humorista nyerte a hídnévversenyt | accessdate = 2008-09-02 | date = 2006-08-22 | work = Index.hu | language = Hungarian }}</ref> which is 7 million more people than there are in all of Hungary. Hungary changed the voting rules after the members of the Colbert Nation Forums developed a [[Internet bot|bot]] to stuff the ballot box, requiring registration to vote in the second phase. That night, Colbert asked his viewers to cease their efforts,<ref name=apologies>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=73378 | title=Colbert Report: Hungarian Bridge | authorlink=Stephen Colbert|first=Stephen|last=Colbert|accessdate=2006-08-28|publisher=[[Comedy Central]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080602154754/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=73378 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-06-02}}</ref> and offered apologies,<ref name=apologies/> spending a segment honoring Hungary, its history, and its contributions to the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=73377 | title=Colbert Report: Stephen Colbert Salutes Hungary | authorlink=Stephen Colbert | first=Stephen|last=Colbert| accessdate=2006-08-28 | publisher=[[Comedy Central]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080420174019/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=73377 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-04-20}}</ref>
On September 14, 2006, Colbert introduced his guest [[András Simonyi]], Ambassador of the [[Hungary|Republic of Hungary]] to the United States. The [[ambassador]] presented Mr. Colbert with a declaration certifying him as the winner of the second and final round of voting. The document bore the signatures of [[Politics of Hungary|Hungarian government]] officials and the [[coat of arms of Hungary|country's official seal]].<ref>{{cite web | publisher =[[Embassy]] of [[Hungary]] | title =Hungarian Ambassador in the Colbert Report | date= 2006-10-15 | url =http://www.huembwas.org/Hirek/Colbert20060915.htm | accessdate = 2007-07-29 }}</ref> Included in the text, as read by the ambassador, were two important conditions required for the name of the bridge to be made official. First, Colbert must be [[fluency|fluent]] in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]]. Colbert responded by pronouncing the Hungarian name ''Nicholas Zrinyi'' (incorrectly referring to [[Miklós Zrínyi]]) and ''híd'' (meaning 'bridge' in Hungarian); Simonyi quickly certified him as fluent.<ref name="thill"/> The second requirement proved more onerous: To have the bridge named after him, Colbert would have to be deceased. Colbert protested, but the ambassador presented him with a [[Hungarian passport]] and [[:Image:HUF 10000 1997 obverse.jpg|10,000 Hungarian Forint]] ([[Hungarian Forint|HUF]]), noting that this would allow Colbert to enter Hungary at any time, without restriction. He also brought attention to the [[portrait]] of King [[Stephen I of Hungary|St. Stephen]], the first King of Hungary, on the 10,000 HUF bill. Finally Simonyi implied that the question of Colbert's ineligibility by virtue of being alive might be resolved if Colbert were to accept an invitation to visit the [[Northern M0 Danube bridge|bridge site]] in [[Budapest]]; Colbert responded by trying to bribe the ambassador with the 10,000 HUF bill.<ref name="thill">{{cite news | last =Thill | first =Scott | title =Bridge to Somewhere | date= 2006-10-15 | url =http://www.huffingtonpost.com/scott-thill/bridge-to-somewhere_b_29493.html | accessdate =2008-09-02 | work=Huffington Post}}</ref> On September 28, 2006, it was announced that the bridge will be named "Megyeri Bridge", although the name did not make it to the second round. According to the Geographical Name Committee, the name was selected because the bridge connects [[:hu:Káposztásmegyer|Káposztásmegyer]] with [[Békásmegyer]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.online.rtlklub.hu/hirek/hazank/?id=0609231745 |title=The M0 Bridge named as Megyeri Bridge |publisher=RTLKlub.hu |date=2006-09-28 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Remix competitions== Colbert sometimes implicitly suggests that his fans remix various aspects of his show simply by telling them not to remix it. In January 2009, he told viewers not to remix his interview with [[Lawrence Lessig]], founder of [[Creative Commons]], which lets authors of creative works share them with the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/216595/january-21-2009/stephen-s-remix-challenge |title=Stephen's Remix Challenge - The Colbert Report - 1/21/09 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> This type of fan involvement is similar to the Colbert Green Screen Challenge, which focuses on video content editing.<ref>[[Colbert report#Green Screen Challenge]]</ref>
==Running for President in 2008== {{Main article|Stephen Colbert presidential campaign, 2008}}
On October 16, 2007, Colbert announced on ''The Report'' that he would be running for president. He had chosen no [[vice-president]], though he was considering choosing [[Vladimir Putin]], [[Mike Huckabee]], or himself as his running mate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediainfo.com/eandp/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003659135|title =Stephen Colbert Officially Announces Run for White House!|accessdate=2007-10-17|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017193759/http://www.mediainfo.com/eandp/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003659135|archivedate=October 17, 2007|date=October 16, 2007}}</ref> Colbert declared that he was only running in [[South Carolina]], his home state, and was contemplating running for both the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] parties as a "[[favorite son]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=118597|title=Colbert '08|publisher=[[Comedy Central]]|date=2007-10-16|accessdate=2008-09-02 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080731231524/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=118597 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Coyle|first=Jake|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hFzxF7XLwi7Il2DVEE6la0NVo--gD8SAOEEG1|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110004541/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hFzxF7XLwi7Il2DVEE6la0NVo--gD8SAOEEG1|archivedate=2007-11-10|title=Stephen Colbert to Run for President|agency=Associated Press|date=2007-10-17|accessdate=2008-09-02}}</ref> Colbert covered his story in the segment "The Hail to the Cheese Stephen Colbert NachoCheese [[Doritos]] 2008 Presidential Campaign Coverage" and promoted his campaign on his special election website colbert08.org, as under law he cannot use colbertnation.com.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=118650|title=Hail to the Cheese|publisher=[[Comedy Central]]|date=2007-10-18|accessdate=2008-09-02 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080510121238/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=118650 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-05-10}}</ref>
On October 21, 2007, Colbert was interviewed by host [[Tim Russert]] on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Meet The Press]]''. Colbert explained why he changed the pronunciation of his name (from "COLE-Bert" to "Cole-BEAR"), demanded to know whether Russert believes that God supports our enemies in Iraq and revealed that he had no interest in ''winning'' the Presidency (he just wanted to run).
On November 1, 2007, the executive council of the [[South Carolina Democratic Party]] voted 13-3 to keep his name off the ballot and refunded his US$2500 filing fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1107/6674.html|title=S.C. Dems reject Colbert candidacy |work=[[Politico.com]]|date=2007-11-01}}</ref> By November 5, 2007, Colbert had officially dropped his Presidential bid.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stephen Colbert Drops Presidential Bid |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/arts/AP-People-Stephen-Colbert.html|agency=Associated Press|date=2007-11-05 |accessdate=2008-09-02|work=The New York Times}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
==Canton insults and apologies== On the July 21, 2008, episode of ''The Colbert Report'', Colbert made a comment about John McCain making a campaign stop in [[Canton, Ohio]], and "not the crappy [[Canton, Georgia|Canton in Georgia]]."<ref name="ajc">{{cite news|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |title=Colbert's 'crappy Canton' comment puzzles mayor |url=http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/cherokee/stories/2008/07/23/colbert_canton_comment.html |date=2008-07-23 |first=Jamie |last=Gumbrecht |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208192542/http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/cherokee/stories/2008/07/23/colbert_canton_comment.html |archivedate=December 8, 2008 }}</ref> The comment resulted in a local uproar, with the Canton, Georgia mayor insisting Colbert had never visited the town along with an invitation for him to do so.<ref name="ajc"/>
On July 30, 2008, Colbert apologized for the story, insisting that he was incorrect and that the real crappy Canton was [[Canton, Kansas]], after which he made several jokes at the Kansas town's expense including calling the town a "shit hole".<ref>{{cite news |work=WXIA-TV |title=Colbert Apologizes To Canton... Sort Of |url=http://www.11alive.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=119248&catid=3 |date=2008-07-31 |first=Paul |last=Crawley}}{{Dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=Kansas City Star |title=Stephen Colbert slams Canton, Kansas |url=http://www.kansascity.com/238/story/728196.html |date=2008-07-31 |quote=In "apologizing" to Canton, Ga., on Wednesday's "The Colbert Report," Stephen Colbert slammed Canton, Kan.}}{{Dead link|date=April 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=177952 "Canton Apology"]. [[Comedy Central]] (2008-07-30). Retrieved on 2008-07-31. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910075440/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=177952 |date=September 10, 2008 }}</ref> Reaction from Mayor Brad Smiley and local residents was negative,<ref>{{cite news |publisher=KWCH-TV |location=Wichita, Kansas |title=Canton Reacts to Colbert Comments |url=http://www.kwch.com/Global/story.asp?S=8771050&nav=menu486_2 |first=Megan |last=Stader |date=2008-07-31}}{{Dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref> while Kansas governor [[Kathleen Sebelius]] invited Colbert to spend a night in Canton's historic jail.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=KWCH-TV |agency=Associated Press |title=Colbert's remarks draws Kan. governor's response |url=http://www.kwch.com/Global/story.asp?S=8769618&nav=menu486_2_7 |date=2008-07-31}}{{Dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref>
On August 5, 2008, Colbert apologized to the citizens of Canton, Kansas, he then maintained that he had meant to direct his mock derision towards [[Canton, South Dakota]], by calling it "North Dakota's dirty ashtray" and satirizing the town in song.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Colbert Report pokes fun at Canton, S.D. |url=http://www.argusleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080806/FRONTPAGECAROUSEL/80806022&referrer=FRONTPAGECAROUSEL |work=Argus Leader |date=2008-08-06}}{{Dead link|date=April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work=The Colbert Report |title=Canton, Kansas Apology |url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=178714 |date=2008-08-05 |first=Stephen |last=Colbert |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910235832/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=178714 |archivedate=September 10, 2008 }}</ref>
On August 12, 2008, Colbert once again apologized to his latest comedic target even though local reaction to the insult was fairly mild. Referring to a line from his satirical song, Colbert said that not all the dogs run away from Canton, South Dakota but "some stay and develop a drinking problem."<ref>{{cite web|work=The Colbert Report |url=http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=179260 |title=Canton, South Dakota Apology |date=2008-08-12 |first=Stephen |last=Colbert |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823135347/http://www.comedycentral.com/colbertreport/videos.jhtml?videoId=179260 |archivedate=August 23, 2008 }}</ref> However, as with the previous apologies, he began a new tirade on another Canton. According to Colbert, [[Canton, Texas]] is nothing but an "incorporated outhouse" and "one steaming pile of longhorn dung." He then asked the audience if they'd seen the town's tourism video. A video then promptly followed showing a monkey humping another monkey with the words Canton, Texas placed in the corner and an arrow pointing from the name to the monkey on bottom.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ktiv.com/Global/story.asp?S=8836138 |publisher=KTIV News Channel 4 |title=Stephen Colbert apologizes to Canton, S.D. |date=2008-08-13}}{{Dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref> This jab at the Texas town had been predicted by Governor Sebelius at the end of her July 31, 2008, remarks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kwch.com/Global/story.asp?S=8769074 |work=KWCH Eyewitness News |title=Governor Responds to "Colbert Report" Jokes |date=2008-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823093709/http://www.kwch.com/Global/story.asp?S=8769074 |archivedate=August 23, 2008 }}</ref> In response to Colbert's comments, a Canton, Texas city councilman joked that he wanted Colbert to come there so he could "mash his nose".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/1130348_Texas_town_responds_to_Colbert_s_outhouse_slam |work=YahooNews |title=Texas town responds to Colbert's 'outhouse' slam |date=2008-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090713155604/http://www.theinsider.com/news/1130348_Texas_town_responds_to_Colbert_s_outhouse_slam |archivedate=July 13, 2009 }}</ref>
On October 28, 2008, Colbert reacted to the news that Barack Obama was campaigning for president in Canton, Ohio — the original good Canton — by saying that he was forced to admit that Canton, Ohio in fact was the ''real'' crappy Canton all along.<ref>{{cite web |work=The Colbert Report |url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/189689/october-28-2008/canton--ohio|title=Canton, South Dakota Apology |date=2008-10-28 |first=Stephen |last=Colbert}}</ref>
==The Colbert Bump== The "Colbert Bump" is defined, connotatively by the ''Report'', as an increase in popularity of a person (author, musician, politician, etc.) or thing (website, etc.) as a result of appearing as a guest on or (in the case of a thing) being mentioned on the show. For example, if a politician appears on ''The Colbert Report'', they may become more popular with certain voters and thus are more likely to be elected. According to a study by [[James H. Fowler]], contributions to Democratic politicians rose 40% for 30 days after an appearance on the show.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://jhfowler.ucsd.edu/colbert_bump.pdf |format=PDF|title=The Colbert Bump in Campaign Donations: More Truthful than Truthy |journal=PS: Political Science & Politics |issue=3 |volume=41 |pages=533–539 |date=July 2008 |author=[[James H. Fowler]] |doi=10.1017/s1049096508080712}}</ref> The [[Mozilla Foundation]] also experienced a noticeable spike in the download rates of the [[Mozilla Firefox|Firefox]] browser right after the launch of Firefox 3 was mentioned in the program.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://blog.mozilla.com/metrics/2008/07/08/colbert-bump-firefox-3-proves-its-existence/|publisher=[[Mozilla Foundation]]|title=Colbert Bump - Firefox 3 Proves its Existence|date=2008-07-08|accessdate=2008-09-30}}</ref> Magazines such as ''[[GQ]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'' and ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' have all had sales spikes when Colbert appeared on their covers.<ref>[https://archive.is/20110615064654/http://www.vanityfair.com/online/politics/2009/12/should-vanity-fair-put-stephen-colbert-on-the-cover.html Should Vanity Fair Put Stephen Colbert on the Cover? | VF Daily | Vanity Fair]</ref>
===Colbert Bump (alcoholic beverage)=== A [[cocktail]] called the ''Colbert Bump'' was designed during the August 4th, 2009, episode of ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' by author David Wondrich. The recipe for a Colbert Bump includes one ounce of [[Peter Heering|Cherry Heering liqueur]], one and a half ounces of [[gin]], a quarter of an ounce of [[lemon]] juice, and a little [[soda water]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/240729/august-04-2009/colbert-bump-cocktail---david-wondrich|publisher=Colbert Nation|title=Colbert Bump Cocktail-David Wondrich}}</ref>
==NASA's Node 3== {{Further|Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill}} In March 2009, [[NASA]] ran an online contest to name the new node of the [[International Space Station]]. Colbert encouraged his viewers to write in his name. By the end, 230,539 "Colbert" votes were cast. This beat ''Serenity'', the top NASA choice, by more than 40,000 votes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swamppolitics.com/news/politics/blog/2009/03/colbert_vs_nasa_congressional.html |title=Colbert vs NASA: Congressional ally |publisher=Swamppolitics.com |date=2012-01-01 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> On April 14, 2009, Astronaut "Suni" Sunita Williams appeared on ''The Colbert Report'', and announced the name of the node to be ''Tranquility.'' However, the treadmill the astronauts use to work out on will be named "C.O.L.B.E.R.T." for "Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill" and this will be located in ''Tranquility.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30217550/ |title=NASA names treadmill after Colbert - Technology & science - Space - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=2009-04-14 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>
The [[Mars Society]] temporarily renamed their [[Mars Desert Research Station]] “Colbert” for one week in April, citing the likelihood that Node 3 would not be given that name in a press release.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mars Society Christens "Colbert Mars Desert Research Station"|url=http://www.marssociety.org/portal/groups/PR_MarketingTF/press-releases-1/mars-society-christens-201ccolbert-mars-desert-research-station201d|accessdate=2 December 2013|newspaper=The Mars Society|date=March 28, 2009|author=Kevin F Sloan|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090413125740/http://www.marssociety.org/portal/groups/PR_MarketingTF/press-releases-1/mars-society-christens-201ccolbert-mars-desert-research-station201d|archivedate=April 13, 2009|location=Hanksville, Utah}}</ref>
==2009 Gulf special== {{Main article|Stephen Colbert (character)#Operation Iraqi Stephen: Going Commando 2009 Visit to Baghdad, Iraq}}
On March 17, 2009, Colbert announced that the show would be broadcasting from somewhere in [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|The Persian Gulf]] at some future date. He did not reveal where and when the taping would occur, as that would have presented a security breach. As part of this he made a segment called "Where in the world and when in time is Stephen Colbert gonna be in the Gulf?" In it he offered vague clues to the location via a ''[[Press Your Luck]]'' board, and described the location being somewhere "sandy" and "packed with troops".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.stripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=61410/|publisher=[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]|title=Colbert heads downrange, maybe New Mexico|date=2009-03-18|accessdate=2009-05-06}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> He repeatedly alluded to places he might go, but refused to divulge specific details. On the May 4 show, director and writer [[J. J. Abrams]] ("[[Lost (TV series)|LOST]]," "[[Alias (TV Show)|Alias]]," [[Cloverfield]]," and ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]'') appeared as a guest, and revealed that he had found out where Colbert was headed and had hidden clues to the location throughout the broadcast, leaving it to the viewers to decipher their meaning.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.argn.com/2009/05/stephen_colbert_speaks_with_jj_abrams_gets_ideas/|publisher=ARGNet|title=Stephen Colbert Speaks With J. J. Abrams, Gets Ideas|date=2009-05-05|accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref> On June 5, 2009, Colbert officially announced that "Operation Iraqi Stephen: Going Commando" would be taping and performing shows in Iraq from June 8 to June 11, 2009, making ''The Colbert Report'' the first TV show in [[United Service Organizations|USO]] history to produce a week of shows in a combat zone.<ref>[http://ccinsider.comedycentral.com/2009/06/05/breaking-stephen-colbert-is-in-iraq/ Breaking: Stephen Colbert Is In Iraq!]. Accessed 2009-06-05. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622051929/http://ccinsider.comedycentral.com/2009/06/05/breaking-stephen-colbert-is-in-iraq/ |date=June 22, 2009 }}</ref> The shows were filmed at [[Camp Victory]] in the [[Al-Faw Palace]].
Colbert's [[head shaving|head was shaved]] on stage by General [[Raymond T. Odierno]], Commander of the [[Multinational Force - Iraq]], at the videotaped order given by President [[Barack Obama]] during the first of four taped performances that were aired June 8, 2009 through June 11, 2009.<ref>[http://www.filterless.net/2009/06/07/stephen-colbert-shaves-head-gives-shout-out-from-iraq/ Stephen Colbert Shaves Head, Gives Shout Out From Iraq] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20090612061620/http://www.filterless.net/2009/06/07/stephen-colbert-shaves-head-gives-shout-out-from-iraq/ |date=2009-06-12 }}.</ref> He wore a civilian [[Suit (clothing)|two-piece suit]], but with a twist: it was tailored from the [[United States Army]]'s [[Universal Camouflage Pattern|UCP digital camouflage pattern]] and featured an [[American flag]] and [[Private (United States)|Private rank insignias]] on the sleeves. Vice President [[Joe Biden]] and Senators [[John McCain]] and [[Jim Webb]] made special appearances, as did former GOP Vice Presidential nominee [[Sarah Palin]] and former Presidents [[Bill Clinton]], [[George W. Bush]], and [[George H.W. Bush]]. Actor [[Tom Hanks]] was also featured heavily in a pre-recorded segment encouraging viewers to support care packages for the troops. At the start of all four episodes filmed in Iraq, Stephen Colbert carried a golf club on stage to honor [[Bob Hope]]'s decades-long service, 250 years according to Colbert, for the USO across the world.
==U.S. Olympic speed skating sponsorship== On November 2, 2009, Colbert, representing the [[Colbert Nation]], signed a sponsorship agreement on-air with U.S. speedskating executive director Robert Crowley after learning of the loss of the team's prominent sponsor: Dutch bank [[DSB Bank|DSB]]. The specifics of this sponsorship are unclear.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> The change of the logo of the U.S. speed skating team's cap, from DSB to Colbert Nation was later shown in the November 12 episode and further episodes. Colbert has also taken aim at [[Canada]], mocking and insulting them, claiming they weren't giving the speed skaters adequate ice time at Olympic rink in [[Vancouver]] in preparation for the [[2010 Winter Olympics]]. The city of [[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond]], where the Olympic Oval is located, had responded with a letter inviting him to be the official [[ombudsman]] at the oval for the Olympics, under the condition that he wear the official ombudsman headgear (a pink [[tuque]]) at all times.<ref name="hrs1"/>
As a result, Stephen attempted to make the US Olympic team in various sports including speedskating in which the final spot would be his if he were to beat [[Shani Davis]] in a 500m race. He lost, but became the Assistant Sport [[Psychologist]] to the US Speedskating team (Colbert holds an honorary [[Doctorate]] in Fine Arts). This perk also ensured that he would be able to be a journalist covering the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] on his own show, and [[NBC]] where he filed speedskating reports during their primetime telecasts with [[Bob Costas]] as host. Conversely, Colbert would also feature NBC hosts and reporters covering the Olympics in his coverage of the games, alongside Olympic athletes, many of whom were from the US Speedskating team.
==Raj Patel's identification as the "Messiah"== [[Benjamin Creme]], self-proclaimed [[esotericist]], and owner of [[Share International]] magazine, identified the coming "[[Messiah]]/[[Maitreya]] (or future [[Buddha]])" as having been: born in 1972; traveled to London from India in 1977; been dark-skinned, and having a stutter. Shortly after [[Raj Patel]], the author of the recent book, "The Value of Nothing" appeared on the show, Creme stated the Messiah had appeared on a popular television program in the United States. Patel was identified as such messiah by Creme's followers, as he fulfilled all of Creme's previous predictions. In the March 15, 2010 show, Colbert claimed this was product of a ''Colbert Bump'' and called Patel on the telephone to confirm his status as the deity, which the author denied. However, Benjamin Creme had also predicted that the Messiah would deny his status, reinforcing his followers' belief in Patel's divine status.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/16/raj-patel-is-the-messiah_n_500645.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Jessie | last=Kunhardt | title=Raj Patel Is The Messiah, Says Religious Group After Author Appears On 'The Colbert Report' (VIDEO) | date=2010-03-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/full-episodes/mon-march-15-2010-robert-baer |title=June 06, 2011 - Werner Herzog - The Colbert Report - Full Episode Video | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=2011-06-06 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>
==Global Zero== [[Queen Noor of Jordan]] appeared on ''The Colbert Report'' to promote [[Global Zero (campaign)|Global Zero]], an [[international]], [[non-partisan]], [[initiative]] to achieve phased, binding, and verifiable elimination of [[nuclear weapons]]. Colbert signed the Global Zero declaration during the interview.
==2006 White House Correspondents Association Dinner== {{main article|Stephen Colbert at the 2006 White House Correspondents' Association Dinner}} Stephen Colbert gave a [[satirical]] speech at the [[2006 White House Correspondents' Association Dinner]] in which he criticized the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration]] and the [[news media]]. The performance earned him praise and scorn in the media.
==2010 Congressional testimony for migrant workers== On September 24, 2010, Colbert testified in character before the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, Citizenship, and Border Security. He was invited by committee chairwoman [[Zoe Lofgren]] to describe his experience participating in the [[United Farm Workers]]' "Take Our Jobs" program, where he spent a day working alongside [[migrant workers]] in upstate [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-09-24/politics/colbert.house.immigration_1_undocumented-farm-workers-migrant-farm-labor-foreign-workers?_s=PM:POLITICS |work=CNN |title=Fresh off farm gig, comedian Colbert testifies in House hearing |date=2010-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114140510/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-09-24/politics/colbert.house.immigration_1_undocumented-farm-workers-migrant-farm-labor-foreign-workers?_s=PM%3APOLITICS |archivedate=2012-01-14 |df= }}</ref> At the end of his often-humorous testimony, Colbert broke character in responding to a question from Rep. [[Judy Chu]], D-CA, and explained why he cares about the plight of migrant workers.
“I like talking about people who don't have any power, and this seems like one of the least powerful people in the United States are migrant workers who come and do our work, but don't have any rights as a result. And yet we still invite them to come here and at the same time ask them to leave. And that's an interesting contradiction to me. And, you know, 'Whatsoever you do for the least of my brothers,' and these seem like the least of our brothers right now... Migrant workers suffer and have no rights.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lippmannwouldroll.com/2010/09/24/stephen-colbert-breaks-character-in-congressional-testimony-to-advocate-for-migrant-workers/ |title=Stephen Colbert Breaks Character in Congressional Testimony to Advocate for Migrant Workers |publisher=Lippmann Would Roll |date=2010-09-24 |accessdate=2012-02-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019012049/http://lippmannwouldroll.com/2010/09/24/stephen-colbert-breaks-character-in-congressional-testimony-to-advocate-for-migrant-workers/ |archive-date=2010-10-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> "
Democratic committee member [[John Conyers]] questioned whether it was appropriate for the comedian to appear before Congress and asked him to leave the hearing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2010/09/colbert_asked_t.html |work=The Boston Globe |first=Donovan |last=Slack |title=Stephen Colbert cracks jokes at Capitol Hill hearing |date=2010-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811113436/http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2010/09/colbert_asked_t.html |archivedate=August 11, 2011 }}</ref> Though Colbert offered to depart at the direction of the committee chairwoman, Rep. Lofgren requested that he stay at least until all opening testimony had been completed, whereupon Conyers withdrew his request.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2010/09/stephen-colbert-testifies-to-congress-today-on-immigration/1 |title=Colbert seriously jokes to Congress about migrant agricultural work |author=Douglas Stanglin |work=USA Today |date=2010-09-24}}</ref>
Conservative pundits took aim at his Congress testimony not long after.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aolnews.com/2010/09/24/stephen-colberts-congressional-testimony-apporpriate-or-waste/ |title=Stephen Colbert Faces Criticism for Congressional Testimony [VIDEO] |publisher=Aolnews.com |date=2010-09-24 |accessdate=2012-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125235407/http://www.aolnews.com/2010/09/24/stephen-colberts-congressional-testimony-apporpriate-or-waste/ |archivedate=2012-11-25 |df= }}</ref>
"As John Conyers notes, the media and spectators turned out to see whether Colbert would address the panel seriously as an expert on immigration and make the panel a joke, or stay in character and make the panel a bigger joke," - [[Ed Morrissey]], [[Hot Air]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://hotair.com/archives/2010/09/24/conyers-to-colbert-we-love-you-but/ |title=Conyers to Colbert: We love you, but … « Hot Air |publisher=Hotair.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref>
=="Keep Fear Alive" rally== After [[Glenn Beck]]'s [[Restoring Honor rally]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], a user on [[Reddit]] suggested that Colbert hold his own Restoring Truthiness rally, and a website and Facebook page for the event were set up overnight.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/09/07/stephen-colbert-restoring-truthiness-rally/ |title=Stephen Colbert being courted for Restoring Truthiness rally |date=September 7, 2010 |author=Archana Ram |work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> A big announcement was first hinted at by [[Jon Stewart]] on September 7,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/tue-september-7-2010/intro---announcement-of-momentous-importance |title=Intro - Announcement of Momentous Importance - The Daily Show with Jon Stewart - 09/07/10 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Thedailyshow.com |date=September 7, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> who ended the show with a [[Moment of Zen]] supposedly holding a clue about the announcement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/tue-september-7-2010/moment-of-zen---jon-s-important-announcement |title=Moment of Zen - Jon's Important Announcement - The Daily Show with Jon Stewart - 09/07/10 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Thedailyshow.com |date=September 7, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> On the same day, Colbert acknowledged the online movement. He played a clip of Beck saying the geese at his event were sent by God, and insisted that he would need his own God geese to tell him to hold a rally. After consulting "Geese Witherspoon" and a bottle of Grey Goose vodka, Colbert responded to Stewart's announcement with a promise to make "an even bigger counter-announcement."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/352238/september-07-2010/geese-witherspoon |title=Geese Witherspoon - The Colbert Report - 9/7/10 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=September 7, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>
The next day, Stewart responded to Colbert's announcement by showing what was going on inside his brain,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/wed-september-8-2010/intro---pre-announcement-brain-camera-zoom |title=Intro - Pre-Announcement Brain Camera Zoom - The Daily Show with Jon Stewart - 09/08/10 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Thedailyshow.com |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> and yet again ended the show with an announcement-related Moment of Zen,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/wed-september-8-2010/moment-of-zen---another-clue-about-the-big-announcement |title=Moment of Zen - Another Clue About the Big Announcement - The Daily Show with Jon Stewart - 09/08/10 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Thedailyshow.com |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> as he did the next day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/thu-september-9-2010/moment-of-zen---another-clue-to-jon-s-announcement |title=Moment of Zen - Another Clue to Jon's Announcement - The Daily Show with Jon Stewart - 09/09/10 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Thedailyshow.com |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>
The following Monday, Colbert finally responded to Stewart, first mocking him for his facial hair, then responding to the "brain-cam" with his own "gut-cam." Colbert then brought up the online rally and how viewers were sending him toy geese and releasing doves outside his studio, finally asking people to stop sending him live animals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/358980/september-13-2010/stop-sending-live-animals |title=Stop Sending Live Animals - The Colbert Report - 9/13/10 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=September 13, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>
To get Colbert's attention, Reddit users also encouraged people to donate to [[DonorsChoose]], a charity organization that benefits teachers across the country. In less than a day, members of the Colbert Nation raised over $100,000. As of October 28, 2010, Reddit raised more than $500,000.
September 15's ''Daily Show'' ended with a [[List of The Daily Show recurring segments#The Toss|toss]] to Colbert, and both acted coy about their competing announcements. That night's ''Colbert Report'' ended with Colbert announcing he would make his big announcement the next day, dropping hints that it would have to do with D.C. and the date October 10, 2010. On September 16, Colbert announced plans to host a 'Keep Fear Alive' rally on the [[National Mall]] on October 30, 2010.
The combined [[Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear]] was duly held on October 30, attracting nearly a quarter of a million participants. As the result of the rally, Metrorail set a new Saturday ridership record of 825,437 trips, as compared to about 350,000 trips on a normal Saturday.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wmata.com/about_metro/news/PressReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=4717 |title=Metro - About Metro - News - Metro sets new record for highest Saturday Metrorail ridership |publisher=Wmata.com |date=October 31, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118193241/http://www.wmata.com/about_metro/news/PressReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=4717 |archivedate=November 18, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Colbert Super PAC== {{main article|Colbert Super PAC}} On March 10, 2011, during a segment on [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential contender]] [[Tim Pawlenty]]'s [[political action committee]] (PAC), Colbert announced the formation of his own PAC <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/377119/march-10-2011/colbert-pac-ad |title=Colbert PAC Ad - The Colbert Report - 3/10/11 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=March 10, 2011 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> and hosted former [[Federal Election Commission|FEC]] Chairman [[Trevor Potter]] on the program to help him fill out the paperwork.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/379369/march-30-2011/colbert-pac---trevor-potter |title=Colbert PAC - Trevor Potter - The Colbert Report - 3/30/11 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=March 30, 2011 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/382014/april-14-2011/colbert-super-pac---trevor-potter |title=Colbert Super PAC - Trevor Potter - The Colbert Report - 4/14/11 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=April 14, 2011 |accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> Troubled by the fact that large corporations were not donating to his SuperPAC, Potter explained that corporations prefer to support political causes when the corporations can remain anonymous. Therefore, he helped Colbert set up a [[501(c)(4)]] Delaware Shell corporation in which donations can be given anonymously without limit and used for political purposes. Colbert asked what the difference was between that and money laundering. Potter answered, "It's hard to say." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/398531/september-29-2011/colbert-super-pac---trevor-potter---stephen-s-shell-corporation |title=Colbert Super PAC - Trevor Potter & Stephen's Shell Corporation - The Colbert Report - 2011-29-09 - Video Clip | Comedy Central |publisher=Colbertnation.com |date=2011-09-29 |accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref> On November 12, Colbert shut down his Super PAC, citing the death of his fictional advisor [[Carl Rove|Ham Rove]]. Potter advised him that by making a check with the remaining funds out to his 501(c)(4), with an "Agency Letter" telling it to transfer that money to a second anonymous 501(c)(4), he would not have to tell anyone - even the IRS - what happened to that money.<ref>{{cite web|title=Colbert Super PAC SHH! - Secret Second 501(c)(4)|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/421160/november-12-2012/colbert-super-pac-shh----secret-second-501c4---trevor-potter|accessdate=November 13, 2012}}</ref>
==Washington Redskins incident== Following the creation of a non-profit organization by the owner of the [[Washington Redskins]], Colbert said that he would create the "Ching-Chong Ding-Dong Foundation for Sensitivity to Orientals or Whatever" in order to bring attention to the hypocrisy of the name. The following day, Suey Park created the hashtag #CancelColbert in order to draw attention to a tweet made by the Comedy Central-operated account of ''[[The Colbert Report]]''. Park interpreted the tweet, which repeated the line from Colbert's show, as a tasteless joke made at the expense of Asians and Asian-Americans. Park's hashtag became a trending topic on Twitter, and the tweet was later deleted.<ref name=Kang>{{cite news|last=Kang|first=Jay|title=The Campaign to "Cancel" Colbert|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2014/03/twitter-campaign-to-cancel-colbert-report.html|accessdate=31 March 2014|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]|date=30 March 2014}}</ref> While the hashtag was trending, Park's efforts were widely criticized by the media. Later stating that he never wants "this to happen again," Colbert deleted the Comedy Central-run account on his show and directed people to follow his personal account.<ref name=PeopleColbert>{{cite web|last=Dowd|first=Kathy|title=Stephen Colbert Destroys His Show's Twitter Account After Controversy|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20802223,00.html|publisher=People|accessdate=2014-04-01}}</ref>
==Amazon.com and Hachette Book Group controversy== On the June 4, 2014 episode, Colbert briefly broke down the details of a dispute that [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] was having with book publisher [[Hachette Book Group USA|Hachette]], who has printed every book he has authored (and is the issuer for thousands more authors). In an ''LA Times'' interview; fellow Hachette author [[James Patterson]] expressed fear in regard to the depths Amazon will go to maintain control over book pricing, publishing, and sales of any e-retail in general.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-amazon-and-hachette-explained-20140602-story.html#page=1/ |title=Amazon and Hachette in 13 easy steps |work=Los Angeles Times |author=Carolyn Kellogg |date=June 3, 2014}}</ref> The main issue between the two companies is of [[e-book]] sales, and Amazon's lowering of prices to what certain publishers consider unsustainable for their business. Considering Amazon's domination when it comes to bookselling (between 40 and 50% of all book sales) and the myriad products it has since taken to selling due to its success with literature, it is slowing down or halting all sales of published or upcoming books produced by Hachette with no end in sight, notifying potential customers that it would be a better decision to shop elsewhere for any Hachette books. In response to his books being delayed or outright banned from being ordered, Colbert (as well as fellow Hachette author [[Sherman Alexie]]) encouraged the Colbert Nation to order ''[[California (novel)|California]]'' from first-time author [[Edan Lepucki]] from [[Portland, Oregon]] bookseller [[Powell's Books]] linked to Colbert's website (as well as "I Didn't Buy It on Amazon" stickers) and urged fans to refuse to purchase anything from Amazon until the conflict is resolved in a fair way.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thecolbertreport.cc.com/videos/t1nxwu/amazon-vs--hachette---sherman-alexie/ |title=Amazon vs. Hachette (Sherman Alexie)}}</ref> On the July 21 episode, Colbert repeated the experiment, asking Lepucki for a recommendation of another Hachette author. Lepucki gave the nod to Stephan Eirik Clark who authored ''Sweetness #9''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/22/giving-another-debut-author-the-colbert-bump/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|title=Giving Another Debut Author the Colbert Bump|author=Alexandra Alter|work=New York Times|date=July 22, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thecolbertreport.cc.com/videos/8e5dyu/colbert-nation-vs--amazon---edan-lepucki}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Demonware, Inc. | logo = New DemonWare logo.png | caption = | type = [[Subsidiary]] | foundation = {{start date and age|df=yes|2003}} | founder = Dylan Collins and Sean Blanchfield | location = [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]]
[[Vancouver]], [[Canada]]
[[Shanghai]], [[China]] | key_people = | industry = [[Video game industry|Computer and video games]]
[[Interactive entertainment]] | products = [[Middleware]] | owner = | num_employees = 177 | parent = [[Activision]] | homepage = {{url|http://www.demonware.net/}} }} '''Demonware''' is an [[Ireland|Irish]] [[Software developer|software development]] company and a subsidiary of [[Activision Blizzard]]. Demonware's products enable games publishers to [[Middleware|outsource their networking requirements]], allowing them to concentrate on playability. The organisation has offices in [[Dublin, Ireland]], [[Vancouver]], British Columbia, Canada, and [[Shanghai, China]]. == History == Demonware was founded in 2003 by [[Dylan Collins]] and Sean Blanchfield.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamedevelopers.ie/features/viewfeature.php?article=130 |title=Game Developers Ireland - Irish Game Development Community |publisher=Gamedevelopers.ie |date= |accessdate=11 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214163106/http://www.gamedevelopers.ie/features/viewfeature.php?article=130 |archivedate=14 February 2012 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/activision-confirms-demonware-acquisition |title=Activision confirms Demonware acquisition | GamesIndustry International |publisher=Gamesindustry.biz |date=6 March 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2012}} In May 2007, the organisation was purchased by [[Activision]]. During the acquisition, Activision offered long-term contracts to the management team and employees of Demonware. Mike Griffith, CEO of Activision, offered the following statement following the corporate acquisition: "The acquisition of Demonware will enable us to eliminate many of the challenges associated with online multiplayer game development, reducing development time and risk, and allowing us to deliver consistent, high-quality online gaming experiences. In addition to increasing our talent pool of highly skilled engineers, Demonware's suite of technologies combined with Activision's own library of tools and technologies will enable us to easily share online development capabilities on multiple platforms across our development studios". == Products == Primary products developed by Demonware include the "Demonware State Engine" and "Matchmaking+". The State Engine is a high-performance state synchronization C++ programming framework that eliminates the need to reinvent [[netcode]] in multiplayer games. Matchmaking+ provides services for multiplayer games such as matchmaking, user profiling, and gaming statistics. Demonware's main product, which is used for multiplayer in the ''Call of Duty'' franchise (among other games) is programmed in [[Erlang (programming language)|Erlang]]{{cite web|url=http://www.erlang-factory.com/upload/presentations/395/ErlangandFirst-PersonShooters.pdf |title=Erlang and First-Person Shooters |publisher=erlang-factory.com |year=2011 |accessdate=11 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120913070310/http://www.erlang-factory.com/upload/presentations/395/ErlangandFirst-PersonShooters.pdf |archivedate=13 September 2012 |df=mdy }} and [[Python (programming language)|Python]]{{cite web|url=http://vimeo.com/31781454 |title=Python at Demonware |publisher=python.ie |year= 2011|accessdate=18 December 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.demonware.net/}} {{Activision}} [[Category:Activision]] [[Category:Software companies of Ireland]] [[Category:Video game development companies]] [[Category:Matchmaking software companies]] [[Category:Video game companies of Ireland]]
